Comment: Nice puzzle that made me think about the most efficient way to set up the conversion functions. I think it is quite fun for a wide variety of coders from novice to experienced.

Hello Lisa-Has-Ideas,

Funny puzzle, I would change the output to set single or plural form of the distance unit:
- Test 4:  "0.6 chains per hour" => "0.6 chain per hour"
- Test 7: "0.1 yards per minute" => "0.1 yard per minute"

That would give a real answer, what do you think ?

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: The tests are well defined and cover a wide array of cases. 

I didn't have any issues with rounding nor the parsing (solved in cpp and ruby with somewhat different methods).

Similar to https://www.codingame.com/training/easy/metric-units but with some extra twists that prevent some straight up copy pasting. Maybe the author wants to add a link to it.

On a side note, the American metric system for distances is really something else, Jesus...
There's are extra spaces after the input for Validator 2 and Validator 9.  Nothing a trim can't fix but I don't think they were intended.

Output section
* Please mention that the decimal place is shown only if it is significant (i.e. non-zero). Otherwise the number is shown as an integer instead of a float.

Alternatively, just always require that convertedSpeed is shown with 1 decimal place.

Cases
* Suggest to rearrange the cases so that each pair of test and validator is similar to each other in terms of the conversion direction. There are 8 basic configurations:
(UD = unit of distance, UT = unit of time,
 G = greater, E =  equal, S = smaller)
   • GUD + GUT to SUD + SUT
   • GUD + EUT to SUD + EUT
   • GUD + SUT to SUD + GUT
   • SUD + GUT to GUD + SUT
   • SUD + EUT to GUD + EUT
   • SUD + SUT to GUD + GUT
   • EUD + GUT to EUD + SUT
   • EUD + SUT to EUD + GUT

* Among UD conversions there are two special cases involving only the greatest and smallest UD, i.e. miles to inches and inches to miles.

Similarly among UT conversions there are two special cases involving only the greatest and smallest UT, i.e. fortnights to seconds and seconds to fortnights.

I would suggest these sepecial cases get paired up by themselves. (not necessarily special UD + special UT; can be special UD + ordinary UT or ordinary UD + special UT. But of course it'll be great to have one pair of special UD + special UT.)

Thanks.

... by the way, solution code
* Not that it matters, but I notice in line 14 that "seconds" is in plural while all the other units are in singular :P

Ah, yes.
Of course, when you point it out, I can see it so clearly now :) 

I have now made those 8 case-pairs plus the 4-pairs for the special cases.

And 2-pairs for the combined extremes

And I forced a ".0" at the end to always show to the tenth.

Perfect advice, as always!!

How is it now??
Oops...  thanks and I fixed it :)

Hey Rafarafa -- thanks.

That puzzle you reference is mildly similar, but it only deals with distances (not speeds), and it's all just multiples of 10, so I think I won't link it.

You call it "the American metric system" but (I learned this only recently), it's actually "the Imperial System" and only the USA, Liberia, and Myanmar still use it.
Interestingly, in the USA, we use metric measures for many things too, so you have to sort of be "bi-lingual"... For example, you buy a 2-liter bottle of soda and a quart of milk.  You drive 45 miles an hour and buy 10-milligram pills.  Your doctor measures you in pounds and inches but when he removes a growth, it's in centimeters.

The ridiculous thing is that in the 1970s (via the Metric Conversion Act of 1975) we (USA) tried to go metric and it just didn't stick.

Hi Odaxav - Thanks for the feedback.  Glad you like it.

re singular vs plural for a fraction.... see the answer that got the most upvotes (62 upvotes) here:
https://english.stackexchange.com/questions/2139/should-we-use-plural-or-singular-for-a-fraction-of-a-mile
which says only use the singular if it's EXACTLY one mile (or unit)

I realize it doesn't totally make sense, but that does seem to be the rule.
And I think it best if I don't add the complication of that
